bestBHT.bht: If a person asks for a fish, they would not expect to be given a serpent, as that would only bring harm upon them. The idea here is that God, as a loving Father, would not deceive or harm His children when they ask for something good. Just as we would not expect to receive a dangerous snake when we desire a fish, we can trust that God will give us what we need and what is beneficial for us. God's gifts are good and He wants to provide for His children's needs. So let us approach Him with confidence, knowing that He will lovingly give us what is good.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: 10. Or if he ask a fish, will he
give him a serpent?—like it, indeed, but only to sting him.
Philip Schaff: Matthew 7:10. A serpent. A response both deceptive and hurtful. We often deem the bread a stone, and the fish a serpent, misunderstanding God’s good gifts.
Archibald T. Robertson: Fish--serpent (ιχθυν--οφιν). Fish, common article of food, and water-snakes could easily be substituted. Anacoluthon in this sentence in the Greek.
John Gill: Or if he ask a fish, will he give him a serpent?
Fish and bread are mentioned, because these were common food.
Nothing of this kind is to be found among men, unless it be among monsters in nature.

bhtAttempts.bht: If a person asks for a fish, they would not expect to be given a serpent, as that would only bring harm upon them. The idea here is that God, as a loving Father, would not deceive or harm His children when they ask for something good. Just as we would not expect to receive a dangerous snake when we desire a fish, we can trust that God will give us what we need and what is beneficial for us. God's gifts are good and He wants to provide for His children's needs. So let us approach Him with confidence, knowing that He will lovingly give us what is good.

Just as no one would give a serpent instead of a fish, God, as a loving Father, would not deceive or harm His children. We can trust that God desires to give us what we need and what is beneficial for us. Let us approach Him with confidence, knowing that His gifts are good and He wants to provide for our needs. Just as a fish is a common food, God's provision in our lives is abundantly available for us to receive. Trust in His faithfulness.

If a person asks for a fish, they would not expect to be given a serpent, as that would only bring harm upon them. The idea here is that God, as a loving Father, would not deceive or harm His children when they ask for something good. Just as we would not expect to receive a dangerous snake when we desire a fish, we can trust that God will give us what we need and what is beneficial for us. God's gifts are good and He wants to provide for His children's needs. So let us approach Him with confidence, knowing that He will lovingly give us what is good.

Asking for a fish and being given a serpent would be deceptive and harmful. Similarly, God, as a loving Father, would not deceive or harm His children when they ask for what is good. We can trust that God will give us what we need and what is beneficial for us. Just as a fish is a common food and expected, so too can we expect God's provision in our lives. His gifts are good and He desires to provide for our needs. Approach Him with confidence, knowing that He is faithful to give what is best.

When someone asks for a fish, they would not expect to receive a serpent instead, as that would only bring harm. This idea illustrates the trust we can have in God as a loving Father. Just as we would not anticipate receiving a dangerous snake when we desire a fish, we can confidently believe that God will provide us with what is good and beneficial. His gifts are always good, and He desires to provide for our needs. Therefore, let us approach Him with confidence, knowing that He will faithfully supply us with what we truly require.
